aspirin,warfarin.description: Increased risk of bleeding due to combined antiplatelet and anticoagulant effects
aspirin,warfarin.mechanism: Additive anticoagulant and antiplatelet effects increase bleeding risk
aspirin,warfarin.clinical_effects: Hemorrhage, bruising, prolonged bleeding time, increased INR
recommendations: Monitor INR closely (weekly initially)
Watch for signs of bleeding (bruising, blood in stool/urine, severe headache)
Consider alternative pain management (acetaminophen preferred)
If combination necessary, use lowest effective aspirin dose

ibuprofen,warfarin.description: Significantly increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding
ibuprofen,warfarin.mechanism: NSAIDs inhibit platelet function and may displace warfarin from protein binding sites, increasing anticoagulant effect
recommendations: Avoid combination if possible
Use alternative analgesics such as acetaminophen
If necessary, monitor INR frequently and watch for bleeding
Consider gastroprotection with PPI

aspirin,ibuprofen.description: Increased risk of gastrointestinal bleeding and reduced cardioprotective effect of aspirin
aspirin,ibuprofen.mechanism: Additive GI toxicity; ibuprofen may block aspirin's antiplatelet effect when taken before aspirin
aspirin,ibuprofen.clinical_effects: Gastric ulceration, GI bleeding, reduced cardiovascular protection
recommendations: Space administration (take aspirin 2 hours before ibuprofen)
Use lowest effective doses for shortest duration
Consider gastric protection with PPI
Monitor for GI symptoms

ibuprofen,lisinopril.description: NSAIDs may reduce the antihypertensive effect of ACE inhibitors
ibuprofen,lisinopril.mechanism: NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis, which can reduce renal blood flow and sodium excretion, counteracting ACE inhibitor effects
ibuprofen,lisinopril.clinical_effects: Increased blood pressure, reduced renal function, hyperkalemia
recommendations: Monitor blood pressure regularly
Check renal function and potassium levels
Consider alternative analgesic (acetaminophen)
Use lowest effective NSAID dose for shortest duration

metformin,simvastatin.description: Possible increased risk of myopathy, though rare
metformin,simvastatin.mechanism: Both drugs can rarely cause muscle problems; combined use may slightly increase risk
metformin,simvastatin.clinical_effects: Muscle pain, weakness, elevated creatine kinase (rare)
recommendations: Monitor for muscle symptoms (pain, tenderness, weakness)
Check CK if symptoms develop
Discontinue if myopathy suspected

amlodipine,simvastatin.description: Increased risk of simvastatin-related adverse effects including myopathy
amlodipine,simvastatin.mechanism: Amlodipine inhibits CYP3A4, increasing simvastatin levels
recommendations: Limit simvastatin dose to 20mg daily when used with amlodipine
Monitor for muscle pain or weakness
Check CK and liver function tests

levothyroxine,warfarin.description: Thyroid hormones may enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin
levothyroxine,warfarin.mechanism: Thyroid hormones increase metabolism of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors
recommendations: Monitor INR more frequently when starting, stopping, or changing levothyroxine dose
Adjust warfarin dose as needed
Watch for signs of bleeding

aspirin,lisinopril.description: Aspirin may reduce the antihypertensive and cardioprotective effects of ACE inhibitors
aspirin,lisinopril.mechanism: Aspirin inhibits prostaglandin synthesis which may counteract ACE inhibitor vasodilation
aspirin,lisinopril.clinical_effects: Reduced blood pressure control, potential reduction in heart failure benefits
recommendations: Monitor blood pressure
Use lowest effective aspirin dose
Monitor for heart failure symptoms in patients with HF

metformin,lisinopril.description: Generally safe combination with potential beneficial effects
metformin,lisinopril.mechanism: No significant pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic interaction
metformin,lisinopril.clinical_effects: Well tolerated; may have complementary cardiovascular benefits
recommendations: Monitor renal function as both drugs are renally excreted
Standard monitoring for each drug individually

amoxicillin,warfarin.description: Antibiotics may enhance warfarin's anticoagulant effect
amoxicillin,warfarin.mechanism: Disruption of vitamin K-producing gut bacteria; possible displacement from protein binding
recommendations: Monitor INR more frequently during and after antibiotic course
Watch for signs of bleeding
May need temporary warfarin dose reduction
